text: Do we have any developer documentation on the HubSpot video stuff yet?  I’m having issues putting one of these videos into a lightbox, if anyone has any light to shed on the situation let me know
we use that when someone say things like: “hello MBF, FYI today im working on VM LTNT in MFL”… ¬¬
so the bot says “human, please, speak in english (spanish)”
Yes I do!
Sorry for the late reply. Been busy

I’ve been thinking of making a tutorial as a side project. Basically I use FTP to add fields that I need to reuse between modules and between websites. I also use it to retrofit older modules with new features/fields.
I do the same sometimes ^
No problem!  Sounds like a cool solution
Can always double check in <#C960Q64G4|design-manager>
just re-posted this in there.
I spoke with Shawn B. He is on it! :slightly_smiling_face:
Here’s the instructions in a nutshell:
I use filezilla. I cannot get codeanywhere to work on HubSpots server…my coworker has the same issue.
To add fields, find the fields.json file that you want to grab fields from, and copy them into a text editor.
I use view/edit.
Then it’s just a matter of copying json to and from the correct area in another fields.json file.

It can be fussy, but I’ve never broken a module by adding fields incorrectly. Typically it seems like the HS server will just reject an error’d fields.json file and revert to a working one. Not really sure :question:
The other thing is, just erase the ID. According to Anthony Pizzuro (HS dev), they are auto-generated and may conflict if not erased. I always just leave quotation marks.
i.e. just erase the ID when injecting the fields into a new module.
When I save the fields file (open from Filezilla), Filezilla will ask if you want to send the updated file to the server. Just say “yes” or “ok” (I forget what it says).
And that’s it. When you refresh your custom module the fields should pop up.
Like I said it can be fussy and I may make detailed instructions.
That's similar to what I do, typically I never touch DM2 IDE, I develop everything(even custom modules) locally. Find it much easier then trying to deal with the IDE
This is great.  I will have to give it a shot
Yeah Bradley I am curious to know what advantages there are with local development.
You don't have to use the IDE haha, I love using sublime
And emmet and all the other plugins
Main reason is so multiple devs can work on a project, we push everything to GitLab, helps not to overwrite anything
